docs.lead_paragraph: The House of Representatives passed a bill tonight that would create federal rights for millions of Americans in managed health care plans, after revising the legislation to limit lawsuits against insurance companies. In approving the legislation by a vote of 226 to 203, the House handed an important political victory to President Bush, who had argued that earlier versions of the bill would encourage frivolous lawsuits.

headline.main: MEASURE DEFINING PATIENTS' RIGHTS PASSES IN HOUSE

docs.abstract: House of Representatives votes, 226 to 203, to approve bill that would create federal rights for millions of Americans in managed health care plans, after revising legislation to limit lawsuits against insurance companies; hands important political victory to Pres Bush, who argued that earlier versions of bill would encourage frivolous lawsuits; under legislation, health insurance plans must provide patients prompt access to medical specialists, must allow women to visit obstetricians and gynecologists without referral and must permit patients to obtain emergency care at nearest hospital, even if it is not affiliated with specific health plan; Democrats hold legislation provides less protection to patients than to health insurance companies; at heart of latest bill is unexpected compromise worked out by Pres Bush and Rep Charlies Norwood; bill would allow patients to sue HMO's in state court for medical decisions, but would put limits on damages; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The House of Representatives passed a bill tonight that would create federal rights for millions of Americans in managed health care plans, after revising the legislation to limit lawsuits against insurance companies.    In approving the legislation...

docs.lead_paragraph: Americans have had to get used to making bigger co-payments when they go to the doctor, as a result of changes in health insurers' policies. Now, a wave of shareholder lawsuits is prompting liability insurers to impose larger co-payments on corporate clients, too. The focus is on policies written to protect corporate executives and board members against suits charging that they did not act in the interest of shareholders -- by, for example, hiding losses or turning a blind eye to overstated revenue.

headline.main: Liability Insurers Pushing Companies to Share Risks

docs.abstract: Liability insurers seek to impose larger co-payments on corporate clients, as wave of shareholder lawsuits and damages increases; want co-payments as high as 25 percent on policies written to protect executives and board members (M)
docs.snippet: Americans have had to get used to making bigger co-payments when they go to the doctor, as a result of changes in health insurers' policies. Now, a wave of shareholder lawsuits is prompting liability insurers to impose larger co-payments on corporate...

docs.lead_paragraph: Rarely can a single member of Congress, especially a rather obscure backbencher, swing so many votes when he switches position on an issue that he changes the outcome of legislation. But that is precisely what Representative Charlie Norwood, Republican of Georgia, did today on the patients' rights bill. Mr. Norwood, a dentist until he was elected to Congress in 1994 and the dominant voice on patients' rights in the House of Representatives for the last six years, broke with the bipartisan group of senators and representatives who favor a bill giving Americans a free hand to sue their health insurance companies. Late on Wednesday, he struck a deal with President Bush to support a bill placing restrictions on such lawsuits.

headline.main: How a Lawmaker Shifted Position on an Issue and Took a Majority With Him

docs.abstract: Article describes in detail how Rep Charlie Norwood, dominent voice on patients' rights in House for last six years, broke with bipartisan group of senators and representatives who favor bill giving Americans free hand to sue their health insurance companies and struck deal with Pres Bush to support bill placing restrictions on such lawsuits; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-13 Bosnian Serb Sentenced To 46 Years for Genocide Radislav Krstic, a former Bosnian Serb general, was found guilty of genocide for his role in the systematic execution of more than 7,000 unarmed Muslim men and boys near the Bosnian town of Srebrenica in July 1995. The verdict by the international war crimes tribunal at The Hague was its first conviction on a charge of genocide in the wars that broke up Yugoslavia. A1 Explosion in West London A blast, apparently from a car bomb, went off near a subway station, injuring at least six people. A4

docs.lead_paragraph: The House approved the overall patients' rights bill, 226 to 203, tonight, with five Democrats crossing party lines. Earlier the House passed an amendment, 218 to 213, to allow limited lawsuits against H.M.O.'s, a measure favored by President Bush. A ''yes'' vote is a vote in favor. Voting ''yes'' on the amendment were 3 Democrats, 214 Republicans and 1 independent. Voting ''no'' were 206 Democrats, 6 Republicans and 1 independent. The following lawmakers crossed party lines:

docs.lead_paragraph: Just when Congressional Republicans had seemed in dangerous disarray, President Bush in a gratifying 24 hours won House passage of his comprehensive energy plan and eked out a victory on a patients' bill of rights. Mr. Bush's back-to-back successes changed the mood in the capital overnight, giving ebullient Republicans a set of issues to carry to the public over the August recess. At a rally on the East Front of the Capitol, party leaders took turns proclaiming that the president had made good on his signature campaign pledge to provide a new kind of leadership.
docs.abstract: Analysis of Pres Bush's back-to-back House victories on his energy plan and on patients' bill of rights; ebullient Republicans Party leaders proclaim that Bush has made good on his signature campaign pledge to provide new kind of leadership; Sen Trent Lott holds Bush has 'changed the tone' in Washington; but change in tone has come only in Republican-run House, and even there his win on patients-right bill was perilously narrow; he has yet to master relations with Democratic-run Senate, where he has been rebuffed and defied on several issues; in fact, two parties are developing distinct agendas; this could lead to season of grand compromises should both parties decide they need legislative achievements to bring to voters in 2002; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Senate Committee Rejects Consumer Panel Nominee The Senate Commerce Committee voted along party lines to reject President Bush's choice to head the Consumer Product Safety Commission, handing him his first nomination loss. By a 12 to 11 vote, Democrats rebuffed the nomination of Mary Sheila Gall, saying her record as a current member of the commission showed an alarming disregard for children's safety and warning that her elevation to chairwoman would benefit manufacturers, not consumers. [Page A1.]

docs.lead_paragraph: Representative Charlie Norwood, the Georgia Republican who has long championed a meaningful patients' bill of rights, apparently sold out his own cause yesterday. Meeting alone with President Bush, Mr. Norwood made a secretive deal on the eve of today's scheduled House vote that left his allies befuddled and angry. Mr. Bush, who happily described the deal as a victory for bipartisanship, actually demonstrated his administration's obsession with winning at all costs. Republicans and Democrats who had worked on the legislation with Mr. Norwood were not consulted. And the bill that the president and Mr. Norwood agreed on seems to more closely resemble the inadequate competing measure that Mr. Bush had been backing than the strong bill of rights that was approved by the House two years ago and the Senate earlier this session.
docs.abstract: Editorial charges that Rep Charlie Norwood, Republican who has long championed meaningful patients' bill of rights, sold out his own cause, meeting alone with Pres Bush to make secretive deal that seems to more closely resemble inadequate competing measure Bush has been backing than strong bill Norwod formerly supported; says Norwood probably sought passage of any law rather than face presidential veto; says Norwood deserves credit for his long fight for patients' rights, but legislators should no longer follow his lead

docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush and Representative Charlie Norwood, the leader of a six-year campaign to enact a patients' bill of rights, said tonight that they had agreed on compromise legislation, clearing the way for House passage of the measure this week. The agreement stunned Mr. Norwood's allies in Congress, who were meeting to discuss strategy at the moment he was going to the White House to shake hands on the deal with Mr. Bush.

headline.main: Deal Is Reached On a Bill to Set Patients' Rights

docs.abstract: Pres Bush and Rep Charlie Norwood, leader of six-year campaign to enact patients' bill of rights, say they have agreed on compromise legislation, clearing way for House passage of measure this week; Norwood's allies in Congress are stunned; agreement is seen as personal triumph for Bush, sparing him from what could have been major political embarrassment if House voted for orginal version of Norwood's bill in defiance of Bush's threat to veto it; compromise would make it easier for patients to sue insurance companies in state court and to collect damages in cases where care is wrongly denied; but agreement would allow employers to take steps to protect themselves from liability; Sen John McCain, chief Senate sponsor of patients' rights bill, says House bill favors HMO over patient; Sen Edward M Kennedy notes that while House bill gives patients right to sue, there is no enforcement mechanism; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In a warehouse in Virginia, tens of thousands of boxes filled with generic fluoxetine, the antidepressant long sold under the brand name Prozac, sit ready to be shipped. After a five-year multimillion-dollar court battle with Eli Lilly, the maker of Prozac, Barr Laboratories says it expects to begin shipping the fluoxetine pills to pharmacies today.

headline.main: Market Place; Drug Maker Is Set to Ship Generic Prozac

docs.abstract: Barr Laboratories expects to begin shipping fluoxetine, its generic version of the antidepressant Prozac, to pharmacies on Aug 2 after five-year court battle with Eli Lilly, Prozac's maker; fluoxetine is expected to yield biggest financial gain ever on a single medicine produced by generic drug maker; thousands of Prozac consumers can expect to buy the generic immediately for discounts of about 30 percent, and much greater discounts will come in spring of 2002 when more companies are allowed to sell low-priced versions of drug; photo graph (M)
